sen.j: 桂川 甫周（かつらがわ ほしゅう）宝暦元年（1751年）- 文化 (元号)6年6月21日 (旧暦)（1809年8月2日）は、医師及び蘭学者。
sen.e: Hoshu KATSURAGAWA (1751- August 2, 1809) was a doctor and Rangakusha (a person who studied Western sciences by means of the Dutch language).
Hoshu KATSURAGAWA (1751- August 2, 1809) was a doctor and Rangakusha (a person who studied Western sciences by means of the Dutch language).
Hoshu KATSURAGAWA (1751- August 2, 1809) was a doctor and Rangakusha (a person who studied Western sciences by means of the Dutch language).

sen.j: 名は国瑞（くにあきら）であり、甫周は通称である。
sen.e: His name was Kuniakira and Hoshu was his common name.
His name was Kuniakira and Hoshu was his common name.
His name was Kuniakira and Hoshu was his common name.

sen.j: 月池・公鑑・無碍庵などの号を用い、字は公鑑。
sen.e: He used Tsukiji, Kokan, and Mugean as Go (pen name) and his Azana (adult male's nickname) was Kokan.
sen.cmt: 月池→Tsukijihttp://pddlib.v.wol.ne.jp/biography/katsura.htm公鑑→Kokan無碍庵→Mugean3つとも定訳不明
sen.e: He used Tsukiji, Kokan, and Mugean as Go (pen name) and his Azana (adult male's nickname) was Kokan.
He used Tsukiji, Kokan, and Mugean as Go (pen name) and his Azana (adult male's nickname) was Kokan.

sen.j: 父桂川家3代目桂川甫三は、前野良沢、杉田玄白と友人で、解体新書は、彼の推挙により将軍に内献した。
sen.e: His father, Hosan KATSURAGAWA, was the third of the Katsuragawa family and Ryotaku MAENO and Genpaku SUGITA were his friends and they presented the Kaitai Shinsho (New Book of Anatomy) to Shogun by his recommendation.
sen.cmt: 桂川甫三→Hosan KATSURAGAWA桂川家→the Katsuragawa family
sen.e: His father, Hosan KATSURAGAWA, was the third of the Katsuragawa family and friends with Ryotaku MAENO and Genpaku SUGITA whom presented their book Kaitai Shinsho (New Book of Anatomy) to Shogun by his recommendation.
sen.cmt: Ryotaku MAENO and Genpaku SUGITA were his friends and they presentedを friends with Ryotaku MAENO and Genpaku SUGITA whom presented their book Kaitai Shinshoに訂正しました。
sen.e: His father, Hosan KATSURAGAWA, was the third of the Katsuragawa family and friends with Ryotaku MAENO and Genpaku SUGITA whom presented their book Kaitai Shinsho (New Book of Anatomy) to Shogun by his recommendation.

sen.j: 弟に、森島中良（蘭学者・戯作者）がいる。
sen.e: He had the younger brother whose name was Churyo MORISHIMA (a Rangakusha and popular novelist).
sen.cmt: 森島中良→Churyo MORISHIMA 「もりしまなから」という読み方を打っているウェブも見ましたが、「ちゅうりょう」が多かったので「もりしまちゅうりょう」としました。戯作者→popular novelist (英辞郎 on the WEB)
sen.e: He had the younger brother whose name was Churyo MORISHIMA (a Rangakusha and popular novelist).
He had the younger brother whose name was Churyo MORISHIMA (a Rangakusha and popular novelist).

sen.j: 桂川家において甫周を名乗るものは2名居り、それぞれ桂川家の祖である桂川甫筑から数えて、4代目と7代目に当たる。
sen.e: There were two men who took the name of Hoshu in the Katsuragawa family and they were the fourth and the seventh generation of Hochiku KATSURAGAWA, who was the patriarch of the Katsuragawa family.
There were two men who took the name of Hoshu in the Katsuragawa family and they were the fourth and the seventh generation of Hochiku KATSURAGAWA, who was the founder of the Katsuragawa family.
sen.cmt: patriarchを founderに訂正しました。
sen.e: There were two men who took the name of Hoshu in the Katsuragawa family and they were the fourth and the seventh generation of Hochiku KATSURAGAWA, who was the founder of the Katsuragawa family.

sen.j: また5代目にあたる桂川甫筑国宝(ほちく・くにとみ)も一時期甫周を名乗った記録がある。
sen.e: And there is a record that Hochiku (Kunitomi) the fifth announced his name as Hoshu during a certain period.
And there is a record that Hochiku (Kunitomi) the fifth announced his name as Hoshu during a certain period.
And there is a record that Hochiku (Kunitomi) the fifth announced his name as Hoshu during a certain period.

sen.j: 桂川家は、第6代将軍徳川家宣から代々将軍家に仕える幕府奥医師であり、特に外科の最高の地位である法眼を務め、その為蘭学書を自由に読む事が許されていた。
sen.e: The Katsuragawa family was a Shogunate Oku-ishi (inner physicians, doctors who treated the Tokugawa family) for generations since the sixth Shogun, Ienobu TOKUGAWA and they served as a Hogen (the second highest rank for Buddhist priests) which was the highest rank for surgeons, and therefore they were allowed to read books for Western studies freely.
sen.cmt: 幕府奥医師→shogunate Oku-ishi (inner physicians, doctors who treated the Tokugawa family)蘭学書→books for Western studies
sen.e: The Katsuragawa family was a Shogunate Oku-ishi (inner physicians, doctors who treated the Tokugawa family) for generations since the sixth Shogun, Ienobu TOKUGAWA and they served as a Hogen (the second highest rank for Buddhist priests) which was the highest rank for surgeons, and therefore they were allowed to read books for Western studies freely.

The Katsuragawa family was a Shogunate Oku-ishi (inner physicians, doctors who treated the Tokugawa family) for generations since the sixth Shogun, Ienobu TOKUGAWA and they served as a Hogen (the second highest rank for Buddhist priests) which was the highest rank for surgeons, and therefore they were allowed to read books for Western studies freely.

sen.j: 死後、両名とも東京都目黒区三田の上行寺の桂川家一門の墓に葬られたが同寺の移転に伴い、現在は神奈川県伊勢原市上粕屋に墓が存在する。
sen.e: After their death, both of them were buried in the grave of Katsuragawa family in Jogyo-ji Temple in Mita, Meguro Ward, Tokyo, but now the grave exists in Kamikasuya, Isehara City, Kanagawa Prefecture due to the relocation of the temple.
sen.cmt: 桂川家一門→Katsuragawa Family神奈川県伊勢原市上粕屋→Kamikasuya, Isehara City, Kanagawa Prefecture
sen.e: After their death, both of them were buried in the grave of Katsuragawa family in Jogyo-ji Temple in Mita, Meguro Ward, Tokyo, but now the grave exists in Kamikasuya, Isehara City, Kanagawa Prefecture due to the relocation of the temple.

After their death, both of them were buried in the grave of Katsuragawa family in Jogyo-ji Temple in Mita, Meguro Ward, Tokyo, but now the grave exists in Kamikasuya, Isehara City, Kanagawa Prefecture due to the relocation of the temple.

sen.j: また、東京都にあるときに史跡指定を受けている為、都指定史跡の看板が神奈川県の同寺内に掲げられている状態である。
sen.e: Since the grave has received a designation of historical site when it was in Tokyo, the signboard of the historical site designated by the Tokyo Metropolitan Government is in the temple in Kanagawa Prefecture.
sen.cmt: 都指定史跡→historical site designated by the Tokyo Metropolitan Government
sen.e: Since the grave had received a designation of historical site when it was in Tokyo, the signboard of the historical site designated by the Tokyo Metropolitan Government is in the temple in Kanagawa Prefecture.
sen.cmt: has received をhad receivedに訂正しました。
sen.e: Since the grave had received a designation of historical site when it was in Tokyo, the signboard of the historical site designated by the Tokyo Metropolitan Government is in the temple in Kanagawa Prefecture.

sen.j: 本稿では4代目甫周について記述する。
sen.e: This text describes Hoshu the fourth.
This article describes about Hoshu the fourth.
sen.cmt: text をarticleに訂正し、aboutを追加しました。
sen.e: This article describes about Hoshu the fourth.

sen.j: いくつかの資料は、7代目桂川甫周 (国興)の次女である今泉みねの子孫の手により早稲田大学に寄贈されており、同大学で公開展も行われた事がある。
sen.e: Some materials were donated to Waseda University by the hand of the descendant of Mine IMAIZUMI who was the second daughter of Hoshu (Kunioki) KATSURAGAWA the seventh and an open exhibition was held at the university.
sen.cmt: 桂川甫周 (国興)→Hoshu (Kunioki) KATSURAGAWA公開展→open exhibition
sen.e: Some materials were donated to Waseda University by the hand of the descendant of Mine IMAIZUMI who was the second daughter of Hoshu (Kunioki) KATSURAGAWA the seventh and an open exhibition was held at the university.

Some materials were donated to Waseda University by the hand of the descendant of Mine IMAIZUMI who was the second daughter of Hoshu (Kunioki) KATSURAGAWA the seventh and an open exhibition was held at the university.

sen.j: また、桂川家の館は東京都中央区 (東京都)築地1丁目10番地にあたり、現在同地に碑が立っている。
sen.e: Moreover the residence of the Katsuragawa family was in 1-10, Tsukiji, Chuo Ward, Tokyo and now the monument is in the place.
sen.cmt: 東京都中央区 (東京都)築地1丁目10番地→ 1-10, Tsukiji, Chuo Ward, Tokyo館→residence
sen.e: Moreover the residence of the Katsuragawa family was in 1-10, Tsukiji, Chuo Ward, Tokyo and now the monument is in the place.
Moreover the residence of the Katsuragawa family was in 1-10, Tsukiji, Chuo Ward, Tokyo and now the monument is in the place.

sen.j: 功績
sen.e: Achievement
Achievement
Achievement

sen.j: 21歳で、オランダの医学書『ターヘル・アナトミア』の翻訳に参加。
sen.e: At the age of 21, he was involved with the translation of "Ontleedkundige Tafelen" which was a Dutch medical text.
At the age of 21, he was involved with the translation of "Ontleedkundige Tafelen" which was a Dutch medical text.
At the age of 21, he was involved with the translation of "Ontleedkundige Tafelen" which was a Dutch medical text.

sen.j: ツンベルクについて外科術を学び、その名はツンベルクの著した『日本紀行』により、海外にも知られていた。
sen.e: He learned a surgery with the guidance of Thunberg and his name was known abroad through "Nihon Kiko" (Thunberg's Travels in Japan) by Thunberg.
sen.cmt: ツンベルク→Thunberg外科術→surgery『日本紀行』→ "Nihon Kiko" (Thunberg's Travels in Japan) 定訳不明http://www.flc.kyushu-u.ac.jp/~michel/publ/misc/1996/199604bthunb.html
sen.e: He learned surgical techniques with the guidance of Thunberg and his name was known abroad through "Nihon Kiko" (Thunberg's Travels in Japan) by Thunberg.
sen.cmt: a surgery をsurgical techniquesに訂正しました。
sen.e: He learned surgical techniques with the guidance of Thunberg and his name was known abroad through "Nihon Kiko" (Thunberg's Travels in Japan) by Thunberg.

sen.j: 教育者としても優れ、幕府が設立した医学舘の教官として任じられた他、享和2年『顕微鏡用法』を著した。
sen.e: He was also an excellent educator and appointed as an instructor of the medical school which Bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a Shogun) established, and he wrote "Kenbikyo Yoho" (microscope usage) in 1802.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処医学舘→医学館 medical school『顕微鏡用法』→"Kenbikyo Yoho" (microscope usage)定訳不明
sen.e: He was also an excellent educator and appointed as an instructor of the medical school which Bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a Shogun) established, and he wrote "Kenbikyo Yoho" (microscope usage) in 1802.

He was also an excellent educator and appointed as an instructor of the medical school which Bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a Shogun) established, and he wrote "Kenbikyo Yoho" (microscope usage) in 1802.

sen.j: 顕微鏡を医学利用した初めての日本人として知られるとともに、その使用法の教授を徳川家斉等に行い、普及に努めた。
sen.e: He was known as the first Japanese who used a microscope for medical purposes and gave lessons to Ienari TOKUNAGA and others how to use microscope and put effort into promoting the microscope.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: He was known as the first Japanese who used a microscope for medical purposes and gave lessons to Ienari TOKUGAWA and others how to use microscope and put effort into promoting it.
sen.cmt: Ienari TOKUNAGA をIenari TOKUGAWA に訂正し、最後のthe microscopeを itに変換しました。
sen.e: He was known as the first Japanese who used a microscope for medical purposes and gave lessons to Ienari TOKUGAWA and others how to use microscope and put effort into promoting it.

sen.j: また、オランダ商館長から贈られた、蝋製の人頭模型を基に、日本初の木造人頭模型の作成を指示したなどの功績が有る。
sen.e: He had achievements that ordered the making of the Japan's first wooden dummy head based on a waxy dummy head presented from the curator of Dutch trading house.
One of his achievements included ordering the making of the Japan's first wooden dummy head based on a waxy dummy head presented from the curator of Dutch trading house.
sen.cmt: He had achievements thatを one of his achievements includedに変換しました。
sen.e: One of his achievements included ordering the making of the Japan's first wooden dummy head based on a waxy dummy head presented from the curator of Dutch trading house.

sen.j: 寛政4年、ロシアから大黒屋光太夫、磯吉が送還された。
sen.e: Kodayu DAIKOKUYA and Isokichi had been returned to Japan from Russia in 1792.
Kodayu DAIKOKUYA and Isokichi were returned to Japan from Russia in 1792.
sen.cmt: had been をwereに訂正しました
sen.e: Kodayu DAIKOKUYA and Isokichi were returned to Japan from Russia in 1792.

sen.j: 翌5年、将軍家斉は、吹上御所に光太夫らを召し出して謁見をした。
sen.e: Shogun Ienari summoned Kodayu and Isokichi to the Fukiage Gosho (the imperial residential palace) and had an audience with them in 1793.
sen.cmt: 将軍家斉→Shogun Ienari吹上御所→Fukiage Gosho (the imperial residential palace)
sen.e: Shogun Ienari summoned Kodayu and Isokichi to the Fukiage Gosho (the imperial residential palace) and had an audience with them in 1793.
Shogun Ienari summoned Kodayu and Isokichi to the Fukiage Gosho (the imperial residential palace) and had an audience with them in 1793.

sen.j: 「かの国(ロシア)では日本のことを知っているか」との質問に光太夫は「いろいろな事をよく知っています。
sen.e: Ienari asked them, 'Does Russia know about Japan?' and 'They know about Japan very well.' Kodayu answered.

Ienari asked them 'Does Russia know about Japan?' and Kodayu answered 'They know about Japan very well....I've heard some Japanese names such as Hoshu KATSURAGAWA and Junan NAKAGAWA. They said that their names appear in the book about Japan.'
sen.cmt: 括弧内の文が分割されていたので一文に戻しました。
sen.e: Ienari asked them 'Does Russia know about Japan?' and Kodayu answered 'They know about Japan very well....I've heard some Japanese names such as Hoshu KATSURAGAWA and Junan NAKAGAWA. They said that their names appear in the book about Japan.'

sen.j: ......日本人としては、桂川甫周様、中川淳庵様という方の名前を聞きました。
sen.e: '...I've heard some Japanese names such as Hoshu KATSURAGAWA and Junan NAKAGAWA.'
sen.cmt: 会話分のため '' をつけ加えました。
sen.e: '...I've heard some Japanese names such as Hoshu KATSURAGAWA and Junan NAKAGAWA.'
'...I've heard some Japanese names such as Hoshu KATSURAGAWA and Junan NAKAGAWA.'

sen.j: 日本の事を書いた書物の中に載っているとの事です」と答えた。
sen.e: 'I've seen their names in the book about Japan.' he answered.
sen.cmt: 会話分のため '' をつけ加えました。
sen.e: 'I've seen their names in the book about Japan.' he answered.
'I've seen their names in the book about Japan.' he answered.

sen.j: このときの書記役は甫周であり、問答を『漂民御覧記』としてまとめた。
sen.e: The amanuensis, on this occasion, was Hoshu and he compiled the dialogues as "Hyomin Goranki".
sen.cmt: 『漂民御覧記』→"Hyomin Goranki" →定訳不明です。http://www.wul.waseda.ac.jp/kotenseki/search.php?cndbn=%98D%90%BC%88%9F
sen.e: The amanuensis, on this occasion, was Hoshu and he compiled the dialogues as "Hyomin Goranki."
sen.cmt: ピリオドを "の中に入れました。
sen.e: The amanuensis, on this occasion, was Hoshu and he compiled the dialogues as "Hyomin Goranki."

sen.j: のちに光太夫を訪ね詳しい話を聞き取り、『北槎聞略』(寛政6年・1794年、現在は岩波文庫)を編み将軍に献上した。
sen.e: He interrogated Kodaiyu, compiled "Hokusa Bunryaku" (A Brief Report on the Northern District [currently published by Iwanami bunko]) in 1794, and presented it to the Shogun.
sen.cmt: 『北槎聞略』→"Hokusa Bunryaku" (A Brief Report on the Northern District) http://pkukmweb.ukm.my/~penerbit/sari/SARI27/sari27(1)-2009[04].pdf#search='hoshu katsuragawa daikokuya'
sen.e: He interrogated Kodaiyu and compiled "Hokusa Bunryaku" (A Brief Report on the Northern District [currently published by Iwanami bunko]) in 1794, and presented it to the Shogun.
sen.cmt: コンマをandに訂正しました
sen.e: He interrogated Kodaiyu and compiled "Hokusa Bunryaku" (A Brief Report on the Northern District [currently published by Iwanami bunko]) in 1794, and presented it to the Shogun.

sen.j: 他に、『新製地毬萬國圖説』(1786年)、『地球全図』(1791年)、『魯西亜志』(1793年)など、外国地理に関する訳書がある。
sen.e: He also has some translation versions of foreign geography, such as "Shinsei Chikyu Bankoku Zusetsu" (New World Map) in 1786, "Chikyu Zenzu" (World Map) in 1791, and "Roshia-shi" (Russian History) in 1793.
sen.cmt: 『新製地毬萬國圖説』→"Shinsei Chikyu Bankoku Zusetsu"(New World Map)『地球全図』→"Chikyu Zenzu"(World Map)『魯西亜志』→"Roshia-shi" (Russian History)3つとも定訳不明
sen.e: He also did a translation of foreign geography, such as "Shinsei Chikyu Bankoku Zusetsu" (New World Map) in 1786, "Chikyu Zenzu" (World Map) in 1791, and "Roshia-shi" (Russian History) in 1793.
sen.cmt: has some translation versions をdid a translationに訂正しました。
sen.e: He also did a translation of foreign geography, such as "Shinsei Chikyu Bankoku Zusetsu" (New World Map) in 1786, "Chikyu Zenzu" (World Map) in 1791, and "Roshia-shi" (Russian History) in 1793.
